lesson.title: AI at Work: The Enterprise Era

learning_outcomes: Create a meeting-minutes prompt that turns a messy transcript into (1) key decisions and (2) action items in a clear Owner–Task–Deadline format.
Rewrite a low-quality workplace email into a professional version by specifying constraints (tone, length, and required sections) and producing two variant drafts.
Translate a plain-English spreadsheet question into a correct Excel formula (e.g., SUMIFS) and explain what each range/criterion does in one sentence.
Explain, at a beginner level, what RAG/enterprise knowledge base chat does (retrieve then generate) and list two situations where it is safer than “memory-only” chat for company policies.
Apply a simple workplace AI privacy checklist to classify data (public, internal, confidential/PII) and choose an appropriate tool category (public vs enterprise) for each.

must_be_true_facts.fact: Widely cited workplace research estimates that interaction/knowledge workers spend about 28% of the workweek managing email and about ~19–20% searching for internal information; meeting time varies by organization, with some datasets reporting meeting load around ~28–32% of the workweek (supporting a lesson-level rounded claim of ~31% as “roughly one-third”).

details.note: Do not attribute all three percentages to a single study unless the chosen source explicitly reports all three; present meeting share as variable and cite the meeting-time source separately.

sources.title: The social economy: Unlocking value and productivity through social technologies
sources.citation: McKinsey Global Institute (2012) — notes interaction workers spend ~28% on email and nearly 20% looking for internal information.

sources.title: Meetings Statistics: How Many Hours Do We Spend in Meetings?
sources.citation: Fellow.app (meeting analytics summary) — reports % of the workweek spent in meetings (e.g., ~28.3% average; ~32% at 1,000+ employee companies).

must_be_true_facts.fact: In 2023, Samsung restricted employee use of public generative-AI tools after reports that staff had uploaded sensitive internal information (including source code) to ChatGPT, raising concerns about data leaving company-controlled systems.

sources.title: Samsung bans use of generative AI tools like ChatGPT after April internal data leak
sources.citation: TechCrunch (May 2, 2023) — reports Samsung’s temporary restriction and cites an internal leak to ChatGPT.

sources.title: Samsung Bans Staff From Using AI Like ChatGPT, Bard After a Sensitive Data Leak
sources.citation: Business Insider (May 2, 2023) — reports a Samsung memo citing a source code leak to ChatGPT and a workplace ban.

must_be_true_facts.fact: GitHub has publicly stated that GitHub Copilot is “already writing 46% of code” and can help developers code faster (GitHub’s own claim; actual impact varies by team, language, and workflow).

sources.title: GitHub Copilot X: The AI-powered developer experience
sources.citation: GitHub Blog — includes the “46% of code” and “up to 55% faster” claims in the Copilot X announcement post.

must_be_true_facts.fact: The CO-STAR prompt framework (Context, Objective, Style, Tone, Audience, Response) is documented by GovTech Singapore’s Data Science & AI Division in its Prompt Engineering Playbook.

sources.title: Prompt Engineering Playbook (Beta v3)
sources.citation: GovTech Singapore (Data Science & AI Division) — Playbook section “The CO-STAR approach to writing your prompts” (updated Aug 30, 2023).

sources.title: Mastering the art of prompt engineering with Empower
sources.citation: GovTech Singapore (tech.gov.sg) — explains CO-STAR and attributes it to GovTech’s prompt engineering playbook.

dont_claim: Don't present the email/meetings/search percentages as universal or as coming from a single study unless the cited source explicitly reports all of them.
Don't promise guaranteed time savings (e.g., “everyone will save 2 hours/day” or “you’ll work 6-hour days”); frame benefits as potential and context-dependent.
Don't claim that anything pasted into a public chatbot “becomes training data” by default; data retention/training depends on vendor policies and settings.
Don't claim “Enterprise = zero risk”; even enterprise tools require policy, access controls, and human review to prevent leaks or mistakes.
Don't imply AI meeting notes, emails, or spreadsheet formulas are automatically correct; require human review and spot-checking.
Don't claim RAG/knowledge-base chat guarantees truth or perfect citations; retrieved sources can be wrong, incomplete, or outdated and must be verified.
Don't overgeneralize the Samsung incident to mean all companies have had identical leaks or that the exact leaked content is publicly confirmed in detail.

rules: Any category score below 8/10 fails the MASTERPIECE gate, even if the total meets the threshold.
